docs.lead_paragraph: Gerard O'Donnell is a firefighter, so his snoring -- which sounds like a chain saw fighting its way through 500 pounds of toffee -- is a problem at work as well as at home. His girlfriend frequently gets up to sleep in her son's bed ''just so she can get a few hours,'' he said.

headline.main: For Those Who Snore Heavily, Implants May Help

docs.abstract: Pillar palatal implant system, treatment for snoring that involves implantation of rigid inserts into soft palate to help keep it from collapsing during sleep, described; other more invasive treatments and surgeries to alleviate snoring discussed; pillar implants can be removed if they are found ineffective; Restore Medical Company, maker and patent holder of treatment, is currently conducting three clinical trials to confirm that device works for at least moderate snorers; graphs; photo (M)
docs.snippet: A new treatment may be faster, cheaper and far less painful than traditional snoring surgery but how well it works is still an open question.

docs.lead_paragraph: On Dec. 23, 1954, a 24-year-old Coast Guard veteran, Richard Herrick, received from his identical twin a remarkable present, a kidney. On that day, doctors at Peter Bent Brigham Hospital in Boston performed the first successful kidney transplant on Mr. Herrick. A painting commemorating the operating room scene hangs in the Countway Library of Medicine at Harvard.

headline.main: An Internet Lifeline, in Search of a Kidney

docs.abstract: Dr Sally Satel describes her personal journey to find live kidney donor to give her kidney before she needed to resort to dialysis to stay alive; discusses ethical concerns over internet site that brokers transplants and other privately arranged organ donation; notes that it is felony to pay for organ donation under National Organ Transplantation Act of 1984; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Debating transplant ethics: Who gets an organ and who dies?
